question: Seriously, Don, I have to report to the Secretary that everything's on schedule. We have plans for your little ray's gun this summer.
answer: As I understand it, guys, there's some major practical difficulties. I'm pushing as hard as I can.

question: Well, Don, you tell those geniuses you've got until the end of the next fiscal quarter to come up with a working model or I'm pulling the plug on the funding.
answer: I'm assured they're on the verge of a major breakthrough.

question: Are you Dr. Atherton?
I just love your television show.
What's Albert Einstein really like?
Oh, I thought you had him on.
answer: No, that was just an actor.

question: Is everyone an actor, then?
But Einstein isn't?
Hello, Mitch.
Nice little display?
What's your medium?
answer: Just Argon. But I have it all structured for HF if I could get some.

question: That would be interesting.
answer: It's all theoretical at this stage, but I have the power supply completely worked out.

question: Very nice.
Listen Doc. This scholarship thing, does he get any kind of whatya call it, signing bonus sort of thing?
answer: Well, no...but by allowing Mitch to progress at an accelerated rate we give him the opportunity to fulfill a far greater portion of his remarkable intellectual potential. Don't you agree?

question: Yeah, I guess. It's just that athletes get, you know, cars and stuff.
answer: Well, I guess we scientists are a little different than athletes.

question: Cheaper.
Your parents...
They're...nice
answer: They're Okay. They just sometimes don't have any idea of what I'm talking about.

question: I'm sure of that. Afraid you're going to miss your friends?
answer: No. I don't have any. I think I intimidate other kids.

question: Good boy.

Remember, compared to you, most people have the IQ of a carrot. We're different than most people, Mitch, but you should be proud of that. I mean, look around. From now on, you'll BE amongst peers, colleagues. I suppose I might as well tell you now, I've put you on my personal research team. Some of the finest minds on campus, not the least of which is, of course, my own.
Well, now, I'm expecting great things from you, my boy. This is only the second time I've given this honor to a freshman. The first was...
You know Chris?
answer: No, but he's a legend in the Physics Club.

question: Well, you're going to become a legend yourself. You'll be working with Chris. He's a senior now but he's still on the team and still as brilliant as ever.
Guys, I want you to meet Chris Kinsley. Chris, this is Sherry Nugil, my assistant, and Mike Dodd.
He's the man who just designed the new Telcom Satellite here.
answer: I know. Nice to meet you Dr. Dodd. Isn't the Telcom raining debris all over Europe? Oh, this. Sorry, I was worried that people would think I was stuffy, You know, no fun; all brain, no penis,

question: Pardon?
answer: I'm sorry, it's just an infantile response to authority.

question: Yes. you are Chris Kinsley, aren't you?
answer: No. Well, yes. I mean, I used to be. Now I'm Mhavishnue Kinsley.

question: I see. You are being funny.
answer: Well, I just can't help it. You're such a fun guy yourself.

question: Oh yes. I think you'll find we all are, right Mike? Now Chris, Sherry is going to show you around the place. She can answer any questions you might have about fringe benefits or dress codes or anything and I'll see you back upstairs when you're done, okay? Sherry, take good care of this young man. He's one of the ten finest minds kin the country.
answer: Someday I hope to be two of them.

question: See you later.
You are very beautiful.
answer: You don't act like one of the top ten minds in America.

question: Oh, really? How many of them have you met?
Really?
answer: You'll be eight. Six was Professor Hostetler at M.I.T.

question: Old Professor Hostetler? Isn't he dead?
answer: He is now. And so, coupled with full insurance coverage and bonus plans, you find it adding up to a fairly sizable perks package.

question: I have a pretty sizable perks package right now.
answer: Also, we understand that you people don't care too much for rigid timetables, and that's pretty rare in private industry.

question: So are you.
answer: Is it true that school of yours keeps getting smarter and smarter kids every year?

question: Yup! I mean no!
answer: You see the funding associations are the same. Our theoretical work is in the Blue Sky sector as well.

question: You have no idea how much I need that kind of continuity in my life right now.
answer: You just belong here, Chris. We have several of Dr. Atherton's former students and they're all doing quite well with us.

question: What number was he?
answer: Two. One of his other students was four.

question: You're wonderful.
Can we go somewhere?
What?
answer: Please I need it. What was your favorite course?

question: I guess right now I'd have to say Fluid Mechanics.
And Gym.
Sorry.
Ultra-high power laser as an energy force for fusion. Tremendous boon to all mankind. And womankind, too.
It's the process for obtaining enormous amounts of energy from forms of hydrogen, like Deuterium and Tritium.
Extracting the fuels is no problem.
Getting them to combine and release the energy is the problem.
It takes temperatures of 100 million degrees Celsius.
So, I'm...
...building...
...a laser...
...that pulses...
...very hot...
...and causes...
...Fusion...
Good afternoon. I'm looking for the President's Freshman Tea. Mitch Simon. I'm a minor.
answer: People, if I might get your attention. Welcome back, freshmen! I take it you all put the Christmas break to good use? Now, if you'll indulge me, I'd like to speak seriously for a moment. You will recall that when I welcomed you to the Pacific institute of Technology a few short months ago I spoke of how we are one of the finest scientific institutions in the world. I think the finest. I mentioned our six Nobel Prize winners, our members of the national Academy of Sciences, and our members of the National Academy of Engineering. This is an intellectual oasis of technological achievement in the dessert of general academic mediocrity we see inmost colleges and universities today. I also spoke of the fact that you are the finest freshmen class we have ever had here. I say this to every freshman class. Each year we raise our entrance requirements and each year there is a group of students like you who meet and surpass those requirements. As you have no doubt already noticed by now, over a third of you are gone. By the end of the year another third of you will have followed them out of Eden and into mediocrity. We want only the best. Hard work and high standards are expected of everyone. And if you aren't up to it Cal tech or M.I.T. might take you, but you don't fit in here. Let me remind you that this place is an opportunity, not a right; a chance not a gift; a working lunch, not a picnic. Welcome back. Several waitresses begin serving tea but the despair of reality creeps over the students and they begin to disperse. Mitch stands waiting for the approaching Dr. Meredith. Oh, yes, Professor Artherton's bright star.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: And I understand you're already on his project. I'm assured you're going to do great things.

question: I hope so.
answer: Let me give you some advice.

question: Thank you.
Okay. I guess I better go now.
answer: I think the young people really appreciate my " getting down" verbally, don't you?

question: How about my shorts.
answer: Hey! Who do you think you're talking to? Are you from the restaurant or not?

question: No. I'm Mitch Simon. I'm a student. Dr. Atherton told me to come up here.
answer: Oh, you're the new stud, are you. Or is it dud?

question: Damn! I wanted that job.
Why? Because it starts at fifty thousand a year, that's why. Plus travel, car, stock options...
answer: Oh. Well, I'm supposed to have a look at your work up to date. Check it over.

question: Check it over.
For what?
answer: Mistakes, I guess. He said you guys are stuck.

question: Let's get something very clear here. Everything you've heard about the supportive student body and the honor code might hold for the rest of the campus, but it doesn't count for squat in here. Which means when jerry's not here, you do what I say. From God to Jerry to me, get it? Hi Jerry.
answer: I've told you before, Kent, you don't get to use my first name.

question: Did I?
answer: Good to see you, Mitch. I'm sure you're all going to become fast friends.

question: We're well on our way already.
answer: Good, because after Mitch is brought up to date, I want the rest of you to take your cues from him. He'll be in charge of the group.

question: What? I mean, good choice, Jerry.
Am I?
Oh, I forgot Kent, I need your help.
Stop it.
Get copies made of everything so young Mitch here can get started checking everything tomorrow.
And then, on your way back, stop at my cleaners.
answer: Don't give it a thought. I enjoy it.

question: Hello? Hello? What kind of place is this?
answer: Hi. Hey, you just gonna sit there admiring the room or are you going to help me with this?

question: What is this thing?
answer: It's a penis stretcher. You want to try it out?

question: No!
answer: Oh really? Well, congratulations, then, No, It's an Iron Mike.

question: What?
I was here for a second this morning...
answer: You didn't straighten the place up, did you?

question: No.
answer: Good. 'Cause all my filth's in alphabetical order.

question: Anyway, I dropped off my luggage and now all my bags are empty.
answer: I put your stuff away for you. It's all in the bottom drawer. Shirts, pants, underwear, shoes. I had a little trouble with your sport jacket, so I threw it out. Nah, only kidding. This one's for you, little Johnny. What a game. I'm Chris Kinsley.

question: We're falling way behind, Jer.
answer: Well, we're not making cheese sandwiches here, you know, Don.

question: That's a good one. I'll have to remember to use that, Jer.
He better be because the company needs a practical working model within four months.
Let me put this another way, Jer. You know all that money we've been spending for development?
Well, when a project gets cut off, the finance boys always run an audit.
Welcome to Pacific Tech's "Smart People On Ice." Ice turned out real good, Ick.
What did you use?
answer: Oh, sure, I tell you then you tell somebody else, and the next thing you know we're in the middle of another ice age.

question: How does he do it?
answer: Well, I'm not an expert, but I think he puts one foot in front of the other and pushes.

question: Not skating. The horsing around. The never studying. I know he's smart. but nobody's that smart.
answer: I don't know how smart he is. Before he even came here he invented a solar battery, which laid the groundwork for the system that provides the energy for Amarillo, at half the cost. He'd be a millionaire today if he been smart enough to make them pay for it. How he pulls the grades, I don't know.

question: I'm Jordan, I realized I'd forgotten to tell you my name, it's Jordan. I heard there was going to be someone new this term, are you a freshman?
Do you have a bed?
Ha ha. I suppose you're in on this, too. Did you make this stuff?
Who's going to clean it up?
answer: Don't have to. It's going to go from solid form directly to gas.

question: Really? What is it?
answer: I'm not saying. But I can tell you that it's fairly rare, and very unstable.

question: You're all a bunch of degenerates.
answer: We are? What about that time I caught you naked with a bowl of Jello?

question: I...you... I was hot and I was hungry. And anyway...Look, Kinsley, you're not number one anymore.
Mighty mouse, here, beat your placement scores by over twenty points.
answer: Really? I guess you think you're pretty hot stuff?

question: Hi, good morning, I thought I saw you come in here, you must be an earlier riser, we met last night, I'm Jordan, remember? I had a sled with me, I made you a sweater.

yeah, it's just something I do with my hands while I'm reading. I hope I got the size right, I'm pretty sure I did, I have a brother so I use him as a sizing comparison, and I have a pretty good eye for that sort of thing, so I just went ahead and made you one because I was, you know, up. Peeing?

I never sleep. I don't know why. It drove my roommate nuts. I mean really nuts, they had to take her away in an ambulance and everything, she's okay now thought but she had to be transfer to an easier school but I don't know if that part has anything to do with being my fault, but still, anyway, if you ever want any help studying at night or just let me know, okay, 'cause I'm just a couple of doors down from you guys and I'm usually up and I wouldn't mind, okay?
Are you finished yet?
Because I'm here?
Isn't that weird? Well, I have to go.

Right, well, don't forget what I said, I'll put the sweater in your room, see you later, tell Chris that if he wants one I'll be happy to make him one but nit today because after classes I'm going to rebuild the back part of my room, you should come down and see it later, I have to go, bye.
answer: bye. Something strange happened to me this morning.

question: bye. Something strange happened to me this morning.
answer: Was it a dream where you see yourself dressed up in kind of sun god robes standing on top of a pyramid with all theses nude women throwing little pickles at you?

question: No
answer: Why am I the only person who has that dream?

question: Liquid nitrogen?
Oh. There's a guy living in our closet.
Who is it?
Is he... safe?
Coming.
answer: What are you doing out there?

question: Floating, sir. And thinking.
answer: I want to see you at my house at six o'clock. Sharp.

question: Sounds fun. Should I bring anything?
answer: How about a proper attitude for a change?

question: You wanted to see me, your joggingness?
answer: Mr. Kinsley. Right on time. What a surprise. Do you run?

question: Only when chased.
It's one of mark's Ickagami's experiments. He's been irradiating corn with strontium. it's his hobby; big food.
It's big popcorn.
answer: Get it away from me. I can't stand it. I hate popcorn. Leave it there. Chris puts the bag down on the porch.

question: Okay. Have you ever considered switching to de-caffeinated coffee?
answer: I want to start seeing a lot more of you in the lab.

question: You want me to work nude?
answer: Very funny, you're a major disappointment to me, Chris.

question: And you to me, Jerry.
And I advanced your project more than any three guys on campus.
answer: That was yesterday. What have you done for me today?

question: Hey, aren't you getting a little obsessive about this? I took in the new kid. He's working his guts out for you.
answer: Your arrogant, disrespectful behavior is distracting him. If you keep it up, you're going to pay for it.

question: Hey, I'm out of here. Delenda Est Cartheo. P.E.I. July one.
answer: You still have to pass, dear boy, and considering the fact that my class is a requisite, it would seem that I would have some control over your destiny. From now on, you and Mr. Simon are going to spend every waking moment working on my power problem and you will solve it by my deadline.

question: Okay, Jerry, but I really think you should see an analyst. Hi. Do me a favor, taste this. Come on, you won't hurt my feelings. Well, too sweet?
Beats me. I just found it in one of the labs.
Come on. I'm just pulling your leg. How are you doing?
answer: I'm stuck. Dr. Atherton says we've got to miniaturize the power supply and you're not helping.

question: Lighten up. It's only a laser. Instead of trying to take that roomful of capacitors over there and putting new perspective. Charge this baby up. Everything you've got.
You'll see. Go
Do it.
Making hamburgers.
Relax, it's just the fuses at the sub station. They'll have it back on in a second. More importantly, did we get a charge?
Follow the yellow brick road.
answer: Have you ever considered the fact that you are completely wasting your life?

question: What if we end up having too much fun and end up failing?
answer: And would that be the end of the world. Milton?

question: Yes, it would.
answer: Yeah, you're right. Maybe you should go back to the library.

question: No, no they're not, they're from a nearby college though.
The Wanda Trossler School of beauty.
Good, Milton. Of the 136 girls, most of them can find guys a lot better than you.
These girls are not used to geniuses. You might impress them.
So, what do you guys do? Just be smart all the time?
What's your major?
Is that like sports medicine?
Oh! Let me ask you something about that. If I was on the moon, Could I like tease hair much higher?
I really should be studying.
answer: Me too. I have a bleaching final tomorrow.

question: Achew.
I'm allergic to suntan oil.
I have something to...
answer: Did you pick up my dry cleaning?

question: Yes I did... there's something you should know.
No, that came out. Chris and Mitch aren't working. They're at a party.
answer: I want to show me where, right after I'm finished here.

question: My pleasure.
answer: Good evening. Tonight we're going to look at something most of us take for granted... the colon. What's it look like?

question: Wanna play?
answer: I'm not very... Sure, all right.

question: Some party, huh?
answer: I guess. How come you're not...

question: Necking?
I'm not gay.
Look, I'm seventeen. I'm brilliant, and I'm hyper kinetic. Guy are a little afraid of me, you know. It'll pass...I hope.
Where's Kinsley. I imagine this was his idea.
Kent!
Kent...let's never fight like that again.
We've been lovers too long to have a silly argument come between us.
Please. Don't speak. You were right. Tonight I'll wear the cowboy suit.
answer: You... Of course not! Nobody knows. I mean, there's nothing to know.

question: Too low. Okay, if you want to leave, go ahead. But you'll miss the fun.
Ick invented a new virus and we're gonna release it in Kent's room.
answer: That's sick! That's a sick thing to do!

question: Hey, I was just kidding, I...
answer: You're always just kidding. There's something wrong with you.

question: Just a second...
answer: The other night I needed your help and all you wanted to do was party.

question: I tried to help you. I tried to help you relax.
answer: Being snubbed by beauticians isn't my idea of relaxing.

question: Student beauticians.
answer: I thought this place was going to be different, but it's just the same. I'm either used or made fun of. In high school they pushed me in a mailbox, did I tell you that?

question: They called me Chris the whiss'...

I think they meant wuss, but it didn't rhyme...when I was three years old, I balanced my father's checkbook so they sent me to school and fired their accountant. My father was so intimidated, he stopped speaking to me. My teacher disliked me because I was smarter than they were, and my classmates hated me because I bell the bell curve. Sound familiar? And tell me why my...why did my mother dress me in white shirts, hush puppies and a briefcase, guaranteeing that a girl would never talk to me?
And then one night, in this room, I was sitting right where you are sitting now. I had a vision. I saw him.
Hopsfield.
answer: Hopsfield? Oh! The guy in the closet.

question: Yeah. Laslo Hopsfield. I followed him. Through the closet; down into the steam tunnels. And down there I saw the most disgusting thing Ive ever seen.

Hopsfield in his pajamas. And I talk to the guy . Turned out that in the Seventies he was the number one stud around here. Smarter than you and me put together. So brilliant, so sharp, so advanced, so long.

He graduated. Went to work for some chemical company. One day someone told him he was making stuff that was killing people. I think it was his mother. He freaked. You see, he was totally unprepared for the real world. He had no philosophy. He thought science was the answer for everything. Yes, you are, Metaphorically speaking. Unless you see that the same thing that has made your life miserable can make it great; your brain. When you're smart, people need you, and you can learn how to work that for fun and profit.
answer: You had a arrangement going with Atherton, don't you? That's why you don't have to study.

question: Hey, I don't carry a briefcase. You're a nice kid. If you leave I'll miss you.
answer: If I stay, what should I do, I mean...

question: Well, the first thing you have to do is get even with Kent. It's a moral imperative.
Hey, Kent, you owe us ten dollars for the gas. He'll never pay us. Wow! Hello.
Jerry asked me to drop by. What did he ask you to do?
Which word didn't you understand?
answer: Are you here for the meeting?

question: What meeting?
Okay.
What do you think you're doing?
Take off those shoes. Stay off the rugs.
I'm withdrawing your recommendation to PEI.
I'm giving Kent the job.
You haven't solved my power problem.
No, you're not. So, I'm going to fail you, so you won't graduate, so you can't take the job. Q.E.D.
answer: I'll pass your exam. We had a deal!

question: Did we? That doesn't sound very ethical.
answer: You can't do this. I'll go to Dr. Meredith.

question: Go ahead. What are you going to tell him. Don't forget, like most scientists, he is an honorable, moral man who thinks everyone else is too. I'll just deny anything you say.
What are you doing?
answer: Self-realization. I was thinking of jumping, but it's only twelve feet.

question: Something wrong?
answer: No. Atherton is going to flunk me out of school.

question: But you had a deal.
answer: Yeah, and he says I didn't deliver. You sleep with pits, you wake up smelly. I think Aristotle said that. It was him or Eva Gabor. At least Hopsfield still has his integrity.

question: Excuse me?
answer: I thought I was so smart. I didn't want to be like the other dumb geniuses like Hopsfield. I though I could use Them., instead of Them using me. But, Guess what?

question: I have to agree. It does appear that you've been the victim of your own erroneous logic.
However, this doesn't mean that you can't get yourself out.
Hard work?
Please, Vito, not in the mailbox again.
Oh... I was just reliving some high school highlights.
answer: Look, you don't have to stay up with me. It's not like we're driving. Get some sleep. You're a growing boy. I hope. Hi, Laslo.

question: Look, you don't have to stay up with me. It's not like we're driving. Get some sleep. You're a growing boy. I hope. Hi, Laslo.
answer: I thought you might want some help so I dug into the computer and got every question Artherton's ever asked on every final he ever given.

question: Gee, I didn't get you anything. Is that them?
answer: No, these are entries for McDonald's Sweepstakes. No purchase necessary. Enter as often as you want. So, I am.

question: Really?
answer: This box makes it one million, six hundred thousand. I should win thirty two point six percent of the prizes, including the car.

question: Kind of takes the fun out of it, doesn't it?
answer: I suppose so. But they set up the rules, and lately, I have come to realize that I have certain materialistic needs.

question: So where are the questions?
I memorized them.
answer: I have to go to sleep now.

question: Want my pajamas?
Jordan?
Who?
answer: I'm Sherry Nugil. And I've been waiting three years for this.

question: For what?
answer: For you to be old enough.

question: For what?
For what?
answer: Why do you keep saying, 'For what?'

question: 'Cause so far it's working great.
answer: Come in. Oh, hi, Mitch. I'm just sanding the floor.

question: Could you turn that off a second?
answer: What's wrong? Why are you sweating?

question: I...I just...I came back from helping Chris and there was this woman in my room.
A woman. I mean she was...blessed
And she wanted to...How can I say this so as not to offend you?
Yeah. I hope you're not offended.
She kissed me. Then she took off her clothes. Then I took off my clothes-she had to help me. I kept blacking out - then... it was unbelievable.
No. That's what was unbelievable.
It's true. I stopped her and told her I didn't want to.
This is my class hour!
answer: We're past the deadline. Don't you understand, Decker's dangerous. We need those plans.

question: It's not ready yet. But it will be. I've got Kinsley cooking now. He'll do it. Believe me, I know how to push that kid's buttons. Here are my drawings for the optics in the sighting system.
answer: Decker wants the laser by the end of the week.

question: Okie-dokie, doc, a house doesn't have to fall on ole Chris Kinsley. No!!!! You bastard. This is your fault. Shit! I deserve that. It all comes back on you in the end. Holy shit! Of course, it's so simple. Echoes, bouncing back at me and you. Mitch?! Laslo! Buddy! Have you seen Mitch?
I failed!

That's true. But never mind that now. It came to me. The power problem. I solved it. Echoes! It's so simple, four little mirrors. It bounces back and supercharges the gas itself. I've got to find Mitch to help me build it but it should increase the power ten-fold at least. If you see him, tell him to meet me at the lab. Bye.
answer: Oh, Chris. How did it go?

question: Great. It was a snap. But Atherton said he's failing me anyway.
answer: That's terrible. You must be feeling awful. Are you all right?

question: Hiya, Jerry, how's it going?
World peace, but I don't think this is the time to discuss it.
answer: What are you doing here? I've already told you you've burned out and you've failed me and yourself miserably.

question: Yes, I know that. But I thought you might be interested.
answer: I'm not interested in anything you have to say.

question: I solved the power problem, Jerry.

As you know, I was working on supercharging the DF by means of a fusion technique using a secondary laser. Well, when I tried it, I discovered Kent had sabotaged it so it collapsed on itself. And I want to thank him for the thought.

The Deuterium and Fluorine take up enough space by themselves, right? Well, the mistake we've been making up to now is in trying to kick up the power by means of yet another outside source. Big and bulky, right? Well, the elegance of this is that by reflecting part of the lasing light back in the gas jets we supercharge the whole deal, increasing the power tenfold with no increase in size.
answer: This is a complete waste of time.

question: Kent. Kent. Wake up, Kent. I'm talking to you, Kent.
I said I'm talking to you.
Yes.
answer: I'm not asleep. I must be overworked.

question: You're not overworked, Kent.
answer: Well, I'm not insane! Am I?

question: That remains to be seen, Kent. But we are having a conversation.
answer: I have to metabolize this. Um... who is this?

question: This is Jesus, Kent, and you've been a very naughty boy.
answer: All right! Who is this?! Bodie? Carter?

question: I am known by many names. I am the One. Turn to me and be saved.
Cut the crap, Kent, you've built a weapon.
I know everything.
That's right, Kent. Where is the laser now?
How would you like to burn for the rest of time?
answer: No, they're testing it on the twenty-seventh but I don't know where. It's classified.

question: Oh.
Nothing. I want you to think about what you've done and repent, and from now on, stop playing with yourself.
That's awful!
answer: You think that hurts? You should've met my Uncle Stan. He was a Weasel.

question: That bad, huh?
answer: No, that was his lodge. The Royal order of Friendly Weasels. Every Wednesday when I was eight, he'd take me down to his lodge meeting and he'd challenge people to call out two five-digit numbers. I had to multiply them in my head faster than a guy could do it on a calculator. They'd bet on me. Of course, after the meeting, he'd take me for ice cream.

question: That's nice.
answer: Well...he'd take me to the supermarket and I had to dip my hand in.

question: Is this Jerome Atherton?
This is Bill Carlisle. I saw your television show the other night about the reproductive system.
answer: Thank you, I hope you enjoyed it.

question: I love it. Everything you said was copied word for word from my book and I expect a lot of money for it.
answer: Need I remind you, it's public television, an attempt to teach people something. And all you can think of is personal greed. It's people like you that make me feel bad about being American.

question: I'm Canadian
Not anymore. Jordan?
You were sleeping.
answer: I was? Gee I guess you relax me.

question: Wow!
I put Jordan to sleep.
It's just something you say at a time like this.
Okay, forget it. Let's go.
answer: Boy, these secret fields are so untrusting.

question: So we can't get on-base clearance.
Get the EEPROMs. Abbott to Costello.
answer: This is Costello. Go ahead, Abbott.

question: Costello, who's on first? We've got the goodies.
answer: We have the target coordinates computed for trajectory adjustment.

question: Hi, Kent.
answer: Oh, I thought you were gone.

question: Not yet. Have you been touching yourself?

Good, Kent. Dad, my father, you know, God, wants to show you something. I've learned not to ask. He wants you to wait on the sidewalk at six thirty nine Ivy Crest Drive at precisely six-oh-eight this morning.
Just wait there and you shall receive a sign. Do not despair and do not go inside.
I think you used too much.
answer: Really? I'm sorry you missed it.

question: Yeah, well, I had to pack.
I'm getting married.
